sen.j: 平等寺（びょうどうじ）は、京都市下京区にある真言宗智山派の寺院。
sen.e: Byodo-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chinzan school of the Shingon Sect located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Byodo-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chinzan school of the Shingon Sect located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Byodo-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chisan School of the Shingon Sect located in Shimogyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 山号は福聚山。
sen.e: The honorific mountain prefix is Fukujusan.
The honorific mountain prefix is Fukujusan.
The sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Fukujusan (Mt. Fukuju).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 本尊は薬師如来。
sen.e: Its principal image is Yakuahi Nyorai.
Its principal image is Yakuahi Nyorai.
Its principal image is Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 因幡堂、因幡薬師の名で親しまれている。
sen.e: It is also affectionately referred to as Inabado and Inaba Yakushi.
It is also affectionately referred to as Inabado and Inaba Yakushi.
It is also affectionately referred to as Inabado and Inaba Yakushi.

sen.j: 観音堂（十一面観音像を安置）は洛陽三十三所観音霊場の第27番札所である。
sen.e: The Kannon-do hall (housing an Eleven-faced Kannon statue) is the 27th temple on the Rakuyo 33 Ttemple Kannon Pilgrimage.
The Kannon-do hall (housing an Eleven-faced Kannon statue) is the 27th temple on the Rakuyo 33 Ttemple Kannon Pilgrimage.
The Kannon-do hall (housing an Eleven-faced Kannon statue) is the 27th fudasho (temples where amulets are collected) of the 33 Temples on Rakuyo (the old capital city of Kyoto) Kannon Pilgrimage.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 京都十三仏霊場第7番。
sen.e: It is the 7th temple on the Kyoto 13 Buddha Pilgrimage.
It is the 7th temple on the Kyoto 13 Buddha Pilgrimage.
It is the 7th temple on the Kyoto 13 Buddha Pilgrimage.

sen.j: 『因幡堂縁起』（『山城名勝志』所収）、『因幡堂縁起絵巻』（東京国立博物館蔵）などに創建の由来が書かれている。
sen.e: The origin of Byodo-ji Temple is refered to in "Inabado engi" ("Yamashiro Meishoshi") and "Inabado engi-emaki" (property of Tokyo National Museum).
The origin of Byodo-ji Temple is refered to in "Inabado engi" ("Yamashiro Meishoshi") and "Inabado engi-emaki" (property of Tokyo National Museum).

The origin of Byodo-ji Temple is referred to in "Inabado Engi" (Legends of the Inabado) (included in "Yamashiro Meisho Shi" (Annals of Yamashiro's picturesque sites)) and "Inabado engi-emaki" (picture scroll of legends of the Inabado) (property of Tokyo National Museum).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 縁起は諸本によって内容に若干の違いがあるが、おおむね次のような話である。
sen.e: There are slight variations regarding the temple's history as described in each text, but the general account is as follows.
There are slight variations regarding the temple's history as described in each text, but the general account is as follows.
There are slight variations regarding the temple's history as described in each text, but the general account is as follows.

sen.j: 大納言橘好古（たちばなのよしふる）の孫である少将橘行平（ゆきひら）は、長徳3年（997年）、因幡国司としての任を終えて京に帰ろうとしていたところ、重い病にかかった。
sen.e: After being made governor of Inaba Province in the year 997, Dainagon (Great Councilor) TACHIBANA no Yoshifuru's grandson Major General TACHIBANA no Yukihira fell severely ill while returning to Kyoto.

After being made governor of Inaba Province in the year 997, Dainagon (Great Councilor) TACHIBANA no Yoshifuru's grandson Major General TACHIBANA no Yukihira fell severely ill while returning to Kyoto.

After being made governor of Inaba Province in 997, hosho (major general) TACHIBANA no Yukihira, who was a grandson of Dainagon (chief councilor of state) TACHIBANA no Yoshifuru, fell severely ill while returning to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 表現を変えました。"great councilor" -> "chief councilor of state" に変更しました。

sen.j: ある夜、行平の夢に貴い僧が現れ、「因幡国の賀露津（かろのつ）の浦に貴い浮き木がある。
sen.e: One night, a Buddhist priest appeared in Yukihira's dream and said "There is a precious piece of wood floating on Karotsu-no-Ura in Inaba Province.
One night, a Buddhist priest appeared in Yukihira's dream and said "There is a precious piece of wood floating on Karotsu-no-Ura in Inaba Province.
One night, a Buddhist priest appeared in Yukihira's dream and said 'There is a precious piece of wood floating on Karonotsu-no-Ura Inlet in Inaba Province.

sen.j: それは仏の国（インド）から衆生を救うために流れついたものである。
sen.e: This drifted here from the country of Buddhism (India) in order to save the mortals of the world.
This drifted here from the country of Buddhism (India) in order to save the mortals of the world.
This drifted here from the country of Buddhism (India) in order to save the mortals of the world.

sen.j: それを引き上げてみよ」と言う。
sen.e: Go and take this piece of wood".
Go and take this piece of wood".
Go and take this piece of wood.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置などを変えました。

sen.j: 行平が賀露津の漁師に命じて、波間に光るものを引き上げてみると、それは等身の薬師如来の像であった。
sen.e: Yukihira gained the assistance of a Karotsu fisherman and, on inspecting something that he saw shining in the waves, he discovered that it was a life-size statue of Yakushi Nyorai.
Yukihira gained the assistance of a Karotsu fisherman and, on inspecting something that he saw shining in the waves, he discovered that it was a life-size statue of Yakushi Nyorai.
Yukihira gained the assistance of a Karonotsu fisherman and, on inspecting something that he saw shining in the waves, he discovered that it was a life-size statue of Yakushi Nyorai.

sen.j: この薬師像を祀ったところ、行平の病は癒え、京に帰ることができた。
sen.e: On enshrining the statue, Yukihira's illness was cured and he was able to return to Kyoto.
On enshrining the statue, Yukihira's illness was cured and he was able to return to Kyoto.
On enshrining the statue, Yukihira's illness was cured and he was able to return to Kyoto.

sen.j: この薬師像は天竺（インド）の祇園精舎の四十九院の1つ、東北療病院の本尊であった。
sen.e: The Yakushi Nyorai statue was the principal image of the north-eastern hospital, one of the 49 buildings of India's Jetavana Grove.
The Yakushi Nyorai statue was the principal image of the north-eastern hospital, one of the 49 buildings of India's Jetavana Grove.
The Yakushi Nyorai statue was the principal image of Tohokuryo Byoin (東北療病院, literally, north-eastern hospital), one of the 49 buildings of India's Jetavana Grove.
sen.cmt: 読みが確認できない施設名の表現を変えました。

sen.j: 行平は薬師像をいずれ京に迎えると約束して因幡を後にしたが、その後因幡を訪れる機会がないうちに長い歳月が過ぎた。
sen.e: Yukihira vowed to take the statue to Kyoto and left Inaba Province behind but many years passed without him gaining the opportunity to visit Inaba Province.
Yukihira vowed to take the statue to Kyoto and left Inaba Province behind but many years passed without him gaining the opportunity to visit Inaba Province.
Yukihira vowed to take the statue to Kyoto and left Inaba Province behind but many years passed without him gaining the opportunity to visit Inaba Province.

sen.j: その後、長保5年（1003年）4月7日のこと、行平の屋敷の戸を叩く者がある。
sen.e: On the 7th day of the 4th month of 1003, someone knocked on the door of Yukihira's estate.
On the 7th day of the 4th month of 1003, someone knocked on the door of Yukihira's estate.
On May 16, 1003, someone knocked on the door of Yukihira's estate.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦にしました。

sen.j: 戸を開けてみると、それは因幡からはるばる虚空を飛んでやってきた薬師像であった。
sen.e: Upon opening the door, it was the Yakushi Nyorai statue that had flown from afar to find him.
Upon opening the door, it was the Yakushi Nyorai statue that had flown from afar to find him.
Upon opening the door, it was the Yakushi Nyorai statue that had flown from afar to find him.

sen.j: 行平は高辻烏丸の屋敷に薬師像を祀った。
sen.e: Yukihira enshrined the statue at his estate in Takatsuji Karasuma.
Yukihira enshrined the statue at his estate in Takatsuji Karasuma.
Yukihira enshrined the statue at his estate in Takatsuji Karasuma.

sen.j: これが因幡薬師平等寺の起源であるという。
sen.e: This is said to be the origin of Inaba Yakushi Byodo-ji Temple.
This is said to be the origin of Inaba Yakushi Byodo-ji Temple.
This is said to be the origin of Inaba Yakushi Byodo-ji Temple.

sen.j: なお、薬師如来像が引き上げられた年を天徳3年（959年）とし、行平は勅命で因幡国一宮に参拝し、京に帰ろうとした際に病気になったとする縁起もある。
sen.e: There are historical accounts that place the year in which Yukihira found the Yakushi Nyorai statue as 959, those stating that Yukihira visited the Ichi-no-Miya (highest ranking shrine) of Inaba Province under imperial order, and those claiming that he fell ill while returning to Kyoto.

There are historical accounts that place the year in which Yukihira found the Yakushi Nyorai statue as 959, those stating that Yukihira visited the Ichi-no-Miya (highest ranking shrine) of Inaba Province under imperial order, and those claiming that he fell ill while returning to Kyoto.

There are historical accounts that place the year in which Yukihira found the Yakushi Nyorai statue as 959, those stating that Yukihira visited the Ichi-no-Miya (highest ranking shrine) of Inaba Province under imperial order, and those claiming that he fell ill while returning to Kyoto.

sen.j: 一説に薬師仏は因幡国にあった在地豪族･因幡氏の氏寺の薬師寺 (因幡国)に安置されていたといい、行平が京都へ持ち去ったとされる。
sen.e: According to one account, the Yakushi Nyorai statue was housed at the private Yakshi-ji Temple (Inaba Province) belonging to the powerful local Inaba clan and it was stolen by Yukihira.
According to one account, the Yakushi Nyorai statue was housed at the private Yakshi-ji Temple (Inaba Province) belonging to the powerful local Inaba clan and it was stolen by Yukihira.
According to one account, the Yakushi Nyorai statue was housed at the private Yakushi-ji Temple (Inaba Province) belonging to the powerful local Inaba clan and it was brought to Kyoto by Yukihira.

sen.j: 奈良における寺院勢力の強勢振りを嫌い、平安京内には、官寺である東寺・西寺以外に寺院を建立することは禁止されていた。
sen.e: The strong influence of Buddhist temple's in Nara was resented and it was forbidden to establish any temples other than the two official temples of To-ji and Sai-ji within Heian-kyo City.
The strong influence of Buddhist temple's in Nara was resented and it was forbidden to establish any temples other than the two official temples of To-ji and Sai-ji within Heian-kyo City.
The strong influence of Buddhist temple's in Nara was resented and it was forbidden to establish any temples other than the two official temples of To-ji and Sai-ji within Heian-kyo Capital.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: ただし、貴族の持仏堂は、建立が認められていた。
sen.e: However, it was permitted for nobles to establish their own private Buddha statue halls.
However, it was permitted for nobles to establish their own private Buddha statue halls.
However, it was permitted for nobles to establish their own private Buddha statue halls.

sen.j: 本寺も、これに相当する。
sen.e: This is the category into which Byodo-ji Temple falls.
This is the category into which Byodo-ji Temple falls.
This is the category into which Byodo-ji Temple falls.

sen.j: また、革堂（行願寺）のような、町堂（辻堂）の建立も認められていた。
sen.e: Town halls (Tsuji-do halls) such as Kodo Temple (Gyogan-ji Temple) were permitted.
Town halls (Tsuji-do halls) such as Kodo Temple (Gyogan-ji Temple) were permitted.
Town halls (Tsuji-do halls) such as Kodo Temple (Gyogan-ji Temple) were permitted.

sen.j: 因幡堂も、これらと並んで町衆の信仰を集めた町堂の代表格である。
sen.e: Inaba-do hall assumed this role and became worshipped at by the townspeople.
Inaba-do hall assumed this role and became worshipped at by the townspeople.
Inaba-do hall assumed this role and became worshipped at by the townspeople.

sen.j: 平等寺の寺号は、承安 (日本)元年（1171年）に高倉天皇によって下賜されたものである。
sen.e: The name "Byodo-ji Temple" was granted by Emperor Takakura in 1717.
The name "Byodo-ji Temple" was granted by Emperor Takakura in 1717.
The name Byodo-ji Temple was granted by the Emperor Takakura in 1717.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをのぞきました。"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 重要文化財（国指定）
sen.e: Important Cultural Properties (Nationally Designated)
Important Cultural Properties (Nationally Designated)
Important Cultural Properties (Nationally Designated)

sen.j: 木造薬師如来立像
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Yakushi Nyorai
Wooden standing statue of Yakushi Nyorai

sen.j: 木造釈迦如来立像
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Shaka Nyorai
Wooden standing statue of Shaka Nyorai

sen.j: 木造如意輪観音坐像
sen.e: Wooden seated statue of Nyoirin Kannon
Wooden seated statue of Nyoirin Kannon
Wooden seated statue of Nyoirin Kannon (the Bodhisattva of Compassion)
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 狂言「因幡堂」の舞台であり、関係が深い。
sen.e: The Kyogen (comic storytellin tradition) entitled "Inabado" is set at Byodo-ji Temple and has a deep connection to the tradition.
The Kyogen (comic storytellin tradition) entitled "Inabado" is set at Byodo-ji Temple and has a deep connection to the tradition.
The Kyogen (comic storytelling tradition) entitled 'Inabado' is set at Byodo-ji Temple and has a deep connection to the tradition.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをのぞきました。

sen.j: 京都市下京区不明門通松原上ル因幡堂町728
sen.e: 728 Inabado-cho, Akezunomon-dori Matsubara agaru, Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City
